anatomical location body part affected: Abdominal area/ gastrointestinal system; visceral and subcutaneous adipose tissue
description: Bariatric (weight loss) surgery is a common intervention for treatment of adults with morbid obesity, defined as body mass index (BMI) of at least 40 kg/m2,and for obese patients with severe comorbid conditions such as type 2 diabetes, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, heart disease, or osteoarthritis (22)

Authors of a 2014 Cochrane systematic review (22 randomized controlled trials [RCTs] with 1798 participants)concluded that bariatric surgery “results in greater improvement in weight loss outcomes and weight associated comorbidities compared with non-surgical  interventions, regardless of the type of procedures used” (23)
Bariatric surgical options can be broadly divided into procedures that restrict stomach volume and those that cause malabsorption of ingested nutrients(1)

The adjustable gastric band and theRoux-en-Y  gastric bypass (RYGP) options are the most common procedures around the world.(2) The vertical sleeve gastrectomy procedure is also commonly used (1,22) –Gastric band – a silicon band is placed around the stomach approximately 1 cm inferior to the gastroesophageal juncture, resulting in a gastric pouch above the band. The band can be incrementally inflated via injection of saline to achieve adequate restriction of stomach volume –RYGP – the stomach is bisected and a small pouch is made. The jejunum (proximal part of the small intestine) is divided below the pyloric sphincter and the distal segment is anastomosed to the gastric pouch. The remainder of the stomach and proximal part of the jejunum are anastomosed back to the small intestine, but these tissues are prevented from direct contact with ingested food –Vertical sleeve gastrectomy – 75-80%  of the stomach volume is resected by being stapled off, leaving a “gastric tunnel”
Gastric banding and sleeve gastrectomy are restrictive procedures (decrease size of stomach reservoir thereby limiting food intake)

RYGB has a restrictive and a malabsorptive component. Only a small gastric pouch remains, and the segment of the small intestine that is bypassed is where bile and pancreatic enzymes would usually mix with food passing through the stomach to facilitate nutrient absorption

Bariatric surgery is effective for weight loss in the majority of patients. Following RYGB patients lost an estimated 65 to 70% of their excess body weight within the first 2 years following surgery(3)
Patients are limited in their food intake following bariatric surgery and the calorie restriction facilitates weight loss

.Although research indicates that bariatric surgery is more effective for treating obesity than diet and exercise,increasing physical activityafter the surgery is an important intervention for maximizing weight loss and preventing weight regain(4,22) –Physical activity counseling and supervised exercise trainingafter bariatric surgery not only promote greater weight control, but may also improve body composition and deficits in physical functioning (5,24)
indications: Patients with a BMI of 35 kg/m2 with associated comorbidities(e.g., diabetes mellitus type-2,  cardiovascular disease, sleep apnea); and morbidly obese patients without comorbidities are the usual potential candidates for bariatric surgery(6,8)

Criteria for potential surgical candidates typically also include the following: –Weight loss history -Failure of previous nonsurgical attempts at weight loss, including commercial programs (e.g., Weight Watchers International Inc., Jenny Craig)(6) -Documented failure to keep weight off or prevent further weight gain using aggressive medical management that included behavioral, pharmacologic, exercise, and low-calorie  diet components (9) –Commitment -Expectation that patient will adhere to postoperative care, including follow up visits, dietary recommendations, and physical activity (9) –Nonpregnant woman; absence of chronic disease unrelated to obesity(7)

ICD-10 codes.Z98.84: Bariatric surgery status (ICD codes are provided for reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: In the United States, bariatric surgery is covered by Medicaid and Medicare, and insurance companies are required to cover bariatric surgery in several but not all states. Throughout the world, bariatric surgery is often covered by insurance plans or national health plans for patients who meet specific criteria. Reimbursement for related physical therapy services will vary depending on insurance contract
presentation signs and symptoms: Comorbidities commonly present include the following: –Diabetes mellitus type 2 –Coronary artery disease -Hypertension –Reduced pulmonary function -Shortness of breath –Musculoskeletal problems -Laxity of ligaments -Osteoarthritis of weight-bearing  joints especially knees -Postural abnormalities including hyperlordosis and anteriorly displaced center of gravity -Muscle weakness secondary to physical inactivity
Dietary concerns, including difficulty consuming sufficient protein and hydration
History of sedentary lifestyle Surgical Indications, Contraindications, & Complications

overall contraindications precautions: Medical clearance should be obtained for obese post-bariatric  patients prior to exercise testing and/orexercise training(9)
Clinicians should be aware that most post-bariatric  patients have comorbidities and may be taking medications that affect their ability to exercise safely(9)
Clinicians should be aware of weight limits of weight-supporting  exercise equipment (e.g., treadmill, cycle ergometer, elliptical trainer) and use bariatric equipment as indicated
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Many patients also report a feeling of stigma associated with having undergone bariatric surgery due to a perception that they sought the “easy way out” by choosing surgery over the hard work and discipline needed for weight loss through diet and exercise(10) ›Vital signs and response to activity should be monitored throughout examination ›Observe relevant contraindications and precautions for weight bearing and mobility in patients with joint degeneration

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document date and type of bariatric surgery. Has the patient had any complications?

course of treatment.medical management: How frequently is the patient seen for follow-up  following surgery and for what reason? Who is on the patient’s medical team? What are the patient’s current prescriptions for diet and activity?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the clinician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition include the following
Lipid profiles, blood glucose levels, and thyroid panel (thyroid-stimulating  hormone (TSH), free T3, and free T4 levels)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help or not
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. Has the patient tried an exercise program previously?

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms if applicable
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms related to obesity and any comorbidity
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, worst and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (AM, mid-day, PM, night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document # of wakings/night. Does the patient have sleep apnea? Does the patient use Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) to sleep? -Bariatric surgery is reported to decrease the severity of sleep apnea -Authors of a 2013 systematic review (69 studies with 13,900 patients) found that over 75% of patients reported an improvement in their sleep apnea after bariatric surgery(21)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing which could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient have history of respiratory compromise? -COPD, asthma, and other respiratory problems are frequently seen in people who are obese -After bariatric surgery, the loss of abdominal and intrathoracic fat reduces restriction of the lower airway, and the loss of excess fat around the neck reduces obstruction of the upper airway, thus enhancing breathing (21) -Obtain results of recent pulmonary function tests if applicable -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document the patient’s history of dieting for weight loss, exercise programs, behavioral counseling, and other attempts to lose weight Bariatric surgery is usually offered only after the patient has failed to lose weight with diet and exercise (22)
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, etc. Musculoskeletal problems are common in people with obesity. Some candidates for bariatric surgery will have already undergone surgery to repair or replace weightbearing joints
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Ask about the nature of the patient’s current lifestyle. Approximately how many hours does the patient sit each day? How much does the patient walk daily?Is the patient employed? What is the nature of the work? Identify potential barriers to weight loss
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document the patient’s functional level and use of any adaptive equipment
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom does the patient live, caregivers, etc. Inquire about family, friend and workplace support. Identify potential barriers to weight loss

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate ›Relevant tests and measures:  (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Measure height and weight and calculate BMI. Measure waist and hip circumference; calculate waist-to-hip  ratio –Practitioners working with morbidly obese patients should be aware that special equipment may be required to accommodate their size (e.g., larger BP cuffs, special weighing scales)(11)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient use any assistive devices? If so, note their condition and appropriateness. Are they being used correctly?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Most severely obese people have impairment of postural control.(12) Assess balance statically and dynamically and throughout functional mobility. May use Berg Balance Scale and/or Romberg test
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: The Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) may be used to obtain and/or maintain a subjective measure of exercise intensity
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pedal pulses. Note signs such as ankle and/or leg swelling, redness, and varicose veins,which could be indicators of venous insufficiencyAssess during functional mobilityAssess ability to perform all types of transfers and bed mobility as indicated. Use the FIM for standardized assessment
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess gait noting deviations and asymmetries. Gait velocity can be measured using the 10 Meter Walk Test (10MWT) –Authors of a study in Finland found that gait patterns changed after bariatric surgery(14) -Most absolute ground reaction force parameters decreased in proportion to weight loss, reflecting a simple mass-driven change in gait after weight loss; however, some parameters decreased more than in proportion to the weight loss. Impulsive loading decreased, which resulted in smoother ground contact and suggest a change in gait strategy (i.e., plasticity)Obesity is a biomechanical risk factor for large joint OA. Weight loss after bariatric surgery can result in reduced loading in the lower limb joints, reducing pain and improving hip and knee joint function –There is no consensus on the benefits of weight loss on joint loading. Effects of sustained weight loss on progression of OA and symptoms related to biomechanical factors need to be demonstrated(20)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess all major muscle groups of the upper and lower extremities using manual muscle testing or dynamometry
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess for skin breakdown. Highly immobile patients may develop pressure ulcers. Accumulation of perspiration and bacteria in skinfolds can also lead to skin breakdown
Observe for alterations in pigmentation and swelling in the legs, which may indicate venous insufficiency
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess in sitting and standing. A heavy protruding abdomenmay contribute to excessive lumbar lordosis and anterior pelvic tilt. Common postural deviations in obese people include abnormal angular deviations between the body axis and limb joints
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Most obese people have deficits in joint range of motion (ROM). Assess joint ROM and flexibility –A sit-and-reach  test may be used for overall flexibility, as able(13) -Decreased capacity to forward flex in both sitting and standing position may occur due to decreased stability or increased fatty tissue in the abdominal area causing a physical barrierIs the patient able to perform ADLs independently? Does the patient require adaptive equipment?
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: –Medical Outcomes Study Short Form (SF-36) –Obesity Adjustment Scale (OAS)

contraindications precautions: Severe cardiac precautions (e.g., symptoms of shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness, nausea, or extreme fatigue)
Infectious diseases (e.g., the flu), upper respiratory infections
Severe mental disorders, behavior that creates safety concerns
Severe pulmonary conditions (e.g., vital capacity < 1 L)
Ostomies, G-tubes,Open  lines (e.g., intravenous), Suprapubic appliances (e.g., catheter)
other: Patients may be at risk for falls. Follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall prevention strategies
Resistance training is contraindicated for the first 6-8 weeks after surgery(4)

Because of the internal (laparoscopic or open) surgery, abdominal exercises are typically not allowed for 4 to 6 months.(4)Obtain physician approval before starting crunches and other exercises requiring significant abdominal work(4)
Ensure adequate hydration during physical activity. Patients may be prone to dehydration due to difficulty with intake of sufficient fluid

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Post bariatric surgery/ exercise program to safely and effectively maximize weight loss, increase cardiovascular fitness and endurance, and improve functional abilities
prognosis: Bariatric surgery is effective for weight loss in the majority of patients. Following RYGB patients lose an estimated 65-70%  of their excess body weight within the first 2 years following surgery(3)

The absolute risk of complications is small. Overall bariatric surgery has an acceptable risk/benefit profile with appropriate patient selection and the availability of an experienced multidisciplinary team(1)
Mortality rates among patients undergoing bariatric surgery vary between 0.5% and 2.0%.(9) Mortality rates of patients over age 65 are generally 2 to 3 times higher than those of younger patients(9)
Bariatric surgery results in significant glycemic improvements(1)

Benefits of bariatric surgery extend beyond weight loss and glycemic control, and include reductions in overall and cardiovascular morbidity and mortality rates, as well as a reduction in cancer incidence (1,22,23)

Bariatric surgery is associated with improved pulmonary functioning and decreased severity of asthma and sleep apnea –Requirement for CPAP in patients with sleep apnea may decrease after bariatric surgery(21)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer to surgeon, physician assistant or nurse practitioner, dietitian, mental health professional, medical weight-loss specialist (bariatrician), bariatric nurse, exercise physiologist, occupational therapist, and sleep disorders specialist as indicated Counseling services –Counseling may help postoperative bariatric surgery patients make sufficient increases in their physical activity. Although many patients report an increase in their physical activity after bariatric surgery, objective measures suggest that most do not meet exercise guidelines for general health.(25)Without support most postoperative patients fail to make sufficient increases in physical activity(5)
other considerations: Ambulatory physical activity after bariatric surgery may improve mental health based on a large cohort (n = 850) study in the United States(15) –Three mental health indicators were assessed: impaired mental health functioning, depressive symptoms, and treatment for depression and/or anxiety –Results demonstrated an inverse relationship between physical activity and indicators of poor mental health -Patients who were active for more minutes each day, who accumulated more daily steps and who achieved more high-cadence  minutes had lower odds of depressive symptoms and lower odds of recent treatment for depression or anxiety  –Results also confirmed that a large portion of patients undergoing bariatric surgery are affected by mental health issues -39.2% reported recent treatment for depression or anxiety, 91.2% of whom reported current taking of antidepressant or anxiolytic medication -The authors concluded that physical activity may benefit patients with depression and anxiety
treatment summary: Authors of a single-blind  RCT (n = 128 patients post-RYGB  surgery) in the United States found that exercise following bariatric surgery improved insulin sensitivity(16) –Participants were randomized to either a 6-month semi-supervised  moderate exercise protocol (n = 66) or to a control group that received health education-only  (n = 62) -Patients in the exercise group received 3 to 5 exercise sessions per week with at least one directly-supervised  session per week to assure target intensity and duration were being achieved -Participants used a heart rate (HR) monitor and recorded exercise logs -Exercise consisted of stationary cycling or treadmill walking at home if equipment available, or walking or cycling outdoors -Participants were encouraged to accumulate at least 30 minutes of exercise per day in either an intermittent or continuous manner, depending on individual’s functional limitations –Outcome measures included insulin sensitivity and glucose effectiveness, determined by an intravenous glucose tolerance test (GTT). Secondary outcomes included peak oxygen uptake (VO2 peak), a measure of cardiorespiratory fitness, and body composition –There was a significant decrease in body weight and fat mass in both groups. Insulin sensitivity improved in both groups; however, exercise produced an additive insulin sensitivity improvement above that of surgery –The exercise group also improved GTTand cardiorespiratory fitness compared with the control group –The authors identified exercise as a useful adjunct therapy for RYGB to promote additional cardiometabolic and physical fitness improvements

Authors of an RCT (n = 19 women with morbid obesity) in Brazil found that a program of aerobic exercise training after bariatric surgery improved heart rate kinetic and cardiac autonomic modulation(17) –Participants were randomized to an exercise training group or a control group. Twelve women with normal BMI (i.e., 18.5 < BMI < 24.9) were also assessed but did not undergo any interventions -The 12-week  exercise training program was implemented 1 month after surgery -Exercise consisted of treadmill walking for 1 hour, 3 times per week –Clinical measures included body anthropometry, record of HR and R-R interval patterns on ECG during the 6MWT, and spirometry. Symptom-limited  maximal exercise testing was completed using the modified Bruce protocol before the training protocol began –The morbidly obese women had slower HR kinetics and altered cardiac modulation during submaximal exercise compared with the women with normal BMI –The exercise program was thus associated with beneficial adaptations in HR variability and faster HR kinetics

Resistance training –Although resistance training does increase caloric expenditure, it has notbeen shown to produce substantial weight loss (4) –Resistance training usually increases muscular strength and endurance, which can lead to being more physically active –Time efficient resistance training sessions (multipoint exercises) are recommended so as not to reduce the time available for aerobic exercise(4) –. Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Morbid obesity or obesity with comorbiditiesMaximize weight loss post-surgeryTherapeutic Exercise _ Emphasis on large muscle groups aerobic activities(9) _ _Progress each individual as indicated considering fitness level, and comorbiditiesProvide patient with appropriate home exercise program focusing on aerobic activity _ _ Monitor regularly  Insulin resistance Improve insulin sensitivityTherapeutic Exercise Focus on aerobic activitiesProgress each individual as indicatedProvide appropriate home exercise program Reduced cardiovascular fitnessImprove cardiovascular fitnessTherapeutic Exercise Aerobic exercise Interval training(10)Progress each individual as indicatedProvide home program of exercises focusing on aerobic activity Reduced lifestyle physical activityIncrease daily physical activityPatient Education Increase unstructured physical activity. _ Decrease sedentarismGradually increase activity until guidelines for health are metEducate patient and family, support-givers on strategies to increase physical activity and decrease sitting Muscle weakness Improve muscle strengthTherapeutic Exercise Progressive resistance exercise _Increase resistance and repetitions as indicated for each unique patientProvide home program of resistance exercises Poor posture and impaired _ postural controlImproved posture and postural controlTherapeutic Exercise Resistance training, posture and balance training, _ functional activities, aquatic exercise,(11) _ biomechanics educationProgress each unique patient as indicatedProvide home program of exercises focusing on functional activities .

maintenance or prevention: Lifestyle intervention in the pre-surgical  and post-surgical  management of patients undergoing bariatric surgery Patients should be encouraged to increase energy expenditure through structured exercise as well as lifestyle physical activity(9) –The American College of Sports Medicine defines lifestyle physical activity as “any nanostructured form of physical activity performed that is not intended to constitute a structured period of exercise”(18)  -For example, walking as a means of commuting to work would be considered lifestyle activity, whereas taking a structured 30-minute  walk for the purpose of exercise would not –An increase in non-exercise  activity thermogenesis of as little as 100 kcal per day may be sufficient to prevent weight gain –Use of pedometers may help increase nonstructured lifestyle activity Physical activity is the best predictor of long-term  weight maintenance(9) Change in physical activity is associated with being able to maintain weight loss in the long term –Maintaining long-term  contact with intervention staff and adoption of healthy eating behaviors are significant predictors of magnitude of weight loss at 24 months, whereas physical activity explains more of the variability in weight regain(18) Ongoing nutritional counseling is important Stress management and social support are helpful for avoiding relapses and making lifestyle changes permanent(9) Prevention of obesity through education, lifestyle intervention, diet, and exercise is preferable and more successful than the therapeutic options for obesity management
patient education: UCSF Medical CenterWeb site: “Life After Bariatric Surgery”https://www.ucsfhealth.org/education/ life_after_bariatric_surgery/

Ina 2011 review of websites onpost-bariatric  exercise programs,the top-rated site was American Council on Exercise (ACE):“After gastric bypass surgery, are there specific precautions I should take?”(19) https://www.acefitness.org/education-and-resources/lifestyle/blog/896/after-gastric-bypass-surgery-are-there-specific-exercise-precautions-i-should-take (accessed 8 November 2017)
